conclusion: To find the magnitude of the external force F applied to slider B, we need to analyze the forces acting on both sliders A and B.
Slider A has gravitational force mg acting vertically downward, normal force NA perpendicular to the inclined plane, frictional force fA acting down the incline, and tension T acting up the incline.

Slider B has gravitational force mg acting vertically downward, normal force NB perpendicular to the inclined plane, frictional force fB acting down the incline, tension T acting down the incline, and external force F acting horizontally to the right.
For Slider A, parallel to the incline: T - mg sin θ - fA = 0.
For Slider A, perpendicular to the incline: NA - mg cos θ = 0.
For Slider A, frictional force: fA = μ NA = μ mg cos θ.
For Slider B, parallel to the incline: F cos θ - T - mg sin θ - fB = 0.
For Slider B, perpendicular to the incline: NB - F sin θ - mg cos θ = 0.
For Slider B, frictional force: fB = μ NB.
Given values: θ = 37°, sin 37° = 0.6, cos 37° = 0.8, μ = 0.5.
For Slider A: T = mg (0.6 + 0.5 × 0.8) = mg.
The magnitude of the external force F is 2mg.
